001package io.github.ai4ci.functions;
002
003import java.util.function.DoubleUnaryOperator;
004
005import io.github.ai4ci.util.Conversions;
006
007/**
008 * Link functions used to transform domain and range values for interpolation
009 * and statistical fitting.
010 *
011 * <p>
012 * Main purpose: provide a small set of commonly used transforms (identity,
013 * logarithm and logit) together with their inverses and derivatives. These
014 * functions are used throughout the numeric pipeline to stabilise fitting and
015 * interpolation (for example transforming probabilities to the logit scale
016 * before fitting splines).
017 *
018 * <p>
019 * Downstream uses: consumed by
020 * {@link io.github.ai4ci.functions.EmpiricalDistribution} and spline/
021 * interpolation helpers to map raw values into a transformed working scale and
022 * back again.
023 *
024 * @author Rob Challen
025 */
026public enum LinkFunction {
027
028        /**
029         * identity link: no transformation, used for unbounded domains and ranges
030         */
031        NONE(
032                        d -> d, d -> d, d -> 1.0, // derivative of identity is 1 (doh)
033                        d -> 1.0, Math.pow(10, 8)
034        ),
035        /**
036         * logarithm link: transforms positive values to the real line, used for
037         * positive domains and ranges
038         */
039        LOG(
040                        d -> Math.log(d), d -> Math.exp(d), d -> 1.0 / d, d -> Math.exp(d),
041                        Math.log(10) * 8
042        ),
043        /**
044         * logit link: transforms probabilities (0â€“1) to the real line, used for
045         * probability domains and ranges.
046         */
047        LOGIT(
048                        d -> Conversions.logit(d), d -> Conversions.expit(d),
049                        d -> 1.0 / d + 1.0 / (1.0 - d),
050                        d -> Conversions.expit(d) * (1 - Conversions.expit(d)),
051                        Conversions.logit(1 - Math.pow(10, -8))
052        );
053
054        DoubleUnaryOperator fn;
055        DoubleUnaryOperator invFn;
056        DoubleUnaryOperator derivFn;
057        DoubleUnaryOperator derivInvFn;
058        double lim;
059
060        private LinkFunction(
061                        DoubleUnaryOperator fn, DoubleUnaryOperator invFn,
062                        DoubleUnaryOperator derivFn, DoubleUnaryOperator derivInvFn, double lim
063        ) {
064                this.fn = fn;
065                this.invFn = invFn;
066                this.derivFn = derivFn;
067                this.derivInvFn = derivInvFn;
068                this.lim = lim;
069        }
070
071        /**
072         * Return the derivative of the forward link evaluated at the supplied domain
073         * value.
074         *
075         * @param x the input value in the original domain
076         * @return the derivative d/dx link(x)
077         */
078        public double derivFn(double x) {
079                return this.derivFn.applyAsDouble(x);
080        }
081
082        /**
083         * Return the derivative of the inverse link evaluated at the supplied
084         * link-scale value. The value is clipped to safe bounds prior to
085         * differentiation.
086         *
087         * @param y a value on the link scale
088         * @return the derivative d/dy invLink(y)
089         */
090        public double derivInvFn(double y) {
091                y = Interpolator.squish(-this.lim, y, this.lim);
092                return this.derivInvFn.applyAsDouble(y);
093        }
094
095        /**
096         * Apply the forward link transform to the supplied value. The result is
097         * clipped to a pre-defined numeric bound to avoid infinities from downstream
098         * spline operations.
099         *
100         * @param x the raw input value
101         * @return the transformed value on the link scale, clipped to safe bounds
102         */
103        public double fn(double x) {
104                double hx = this.fn.applyAsDouble(x);
105                return Interpolator.squish(-this.lim, hx, this.lim);
106        }
107
108        /**
109         * Returns the maximum supported value for this link's domain. Values above
110         * this limit are considered outside the useful support of the function and
111         * are typically clipped by higher-level code.
112         *
113         * @return the maximum supported input value for the inverse link
114         */
115        public double getMaxSupport() { return this.invFn(this.lim); }
116
117        /**
118         * Returns the minimum supported value for this link's domain. Values below
119         * this limit are considered outside the useful support of the function and
120         * are typically clipped by higher-level code.
121         *
122         * @return the minimum supported input value for the inverse link
123         */
124        public double getMinSupport() { return this.invFn(-this.lim); }
125
126        /**
127         * Returns true if the supplied domain value lies strictly within the numeric
128         * support limits for this link.
129         *
130         * @param x the value to test
131         * @return {@code true} if the value is within support, otherwise
132         *         {@code false}
133         */
134        public boolean inSupport(double x) {
135                return this.fn(x) > -this.lim && this.fn(x) < this.lim;
136        }
137
138        /**
139         * Apply the inverse link (transform from link scale back to the original
140         * domain). The supplied value is clipped to safe bounds before inversion.
141         *
142         * @param y a value on the link scale
143         * @return the inverse-transformed value in the original domain
144         */
145        public double invFn(double y) {
146                y = Interpolator.squish(-this.lim, y, this.lim);
147                return this.invFn.applyAsDouble(y);
148        }
149
150}
